SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class CombinationsWithRepetition

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.CombinationsWithRepetition
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<int[]>
public class CombinationsWithRepetition extends Object implements Iterable<int[]>
Generates all k-combinations with repetition (a.k.a. multisets) from the integer domain {0, 1, ..., n-1} and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.

What is a combination with repetition?

We choose k elements from n types, allowing repeats, and where order does not matter. We represent each multiset as a non-decreasing array of indices of length k. For example, with n = 3 and k = 2, the outputs are: 


 [0,0], [0,1], [0,2], [1,1], [1,2], [2,2]

Order of generation

Arrays are produced in lexicographic order subject to the non-decreasing constraint. The first array is [0,0,...,0] and the last is [n-1, n-1, ..., n-1].

How many are there? (Stars and Bars)

The number of multisets is the binomial coefficient C(n + k - 1, k). This is available via size().

Algorithm (lexicographic successor under non-decreasing constraint)

Maintain the current array a[0..k-1] (non-decreasing). To advance:

  1. Scan from right to left for the first position i where a[i] < n-1.
  2. If no such i exists, we are done.
  3. Increment a[i]++, then set all suffix positions a[i+1..k-1] equal to a[i] (this keeps the sequence non-decreasing and lexicographically minimal).

Correctness intuition

  • Exhaustiveness: Starting at [0,0,...,0] and repeatedly applying the successor rule enumerates every non-decreasing k-tuple until we reach [n-1,...,n-1].
  • No duplicates: The successor is deterministic and strictly increases in lexicographic order.
  • Ordering: We always bump the rightmost possible position and minimize the suffix, yielding standard lexicographic order subject to the constraint.

Complexity

  • Time per tuple: O(k) (short right-to-left scan and suffix reset).
  • Total tuples: C(n + k - 1, k) â€” see size().
  • Space: O(k) internal state. Each call to Iterator.next() returns a defensive copy so callers can safely mutate their copy without affecting iteration.

Edge cases

  • k == 0: a single empty array [] is emitted.
  • n == 0: emits nothing unless k == 0 (there are no elements to choose).
  • Invalid inputs (negative n or k) throw IllegalArgumentException.

Example


 CombinationsWithRepetition m = new CombinationsWithRepetition(2, 3);
 System.out.println("Total: " + m.size()); // prints C(3+2-1, 2) = C(4,2) = 6
 for (int[] t : m) {
     System.out.printf("[%d,%d]%n", t[0], t[1]);
 }

Implementation note: Each next() clones the internal array to preserve iterator integrity.

Since:
0.1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • CombinationsWithRepetition

      public CombinationsWithRepetition(int k, int n)
      Constructs a generator of k-combinations with repetition from {0..n-1}.
      Parameters:
      k - multiset size (must satisfy k >= 0)
      n - number of distinct element types (must satisfy n >= 0)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if k < 0 or n < 0

  • Method Details

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the total number of k-combinations with repetition of n items. This is the binomial coefficient C(n + k - 1, k).

      Note: this uses long and will overflow for large inputs. For classroom-scale values it is typically fine. For arbitrary precision, supply a BigInteger variant.

      Returns:
      C(n + k - 1, k) as a long

    • iterator

      public Iterator<int[]> iterator()
      Returns a fresh iterator positioned at the first non-decreasing tuple [0,0,...,0] (or the empty array if k == 0). If n == 0 and k > 0, the iterator is empty.
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<int[]>
      Returns:
      iterator over lexicographically ordered non-decreasing k-tuples
